title: Photoelectric effect - work function and energy

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Monochromatic light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> shines on a metal with a work function <math alttext="phi" overflow="scroll"> <mi>ϕ</mi> </math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The wavelength of the light is varied, and for some wavelengths electrons are emitted from the metal. The maximum speed <math alttext="v sub maximum" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>v</mi> <mi>max</mi> </msub> </math> of the emitted electrons is measured as a function of the wavelength of the light.
content.question:
(a)

i. Derive an expression for the work function of the metal in terms of the wavelength of the light <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>, the maximum speed of the emitted electrons <math alttext="v sub maximum" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

frqParts.text:
(a)

i. Derive an expression for the work function of the metal in terms of the wavelength of the light <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>, the maximum speed of the emitted electrons <math alttext="v sub maximum" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. When light of wavelength <math alttext="200 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></math> shines on the metal, the maximum speed of the emitted electrons is <math alttext="6.5 times 10 to the 5 power, meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>. Calculate the work function of the metal.

iii. The graph in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shows the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electrons as a function of the frequency of the light for the metal. The original metal is then replaced with a different metal with a greater work function than that of the original metal. On the graph in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a line or curve that could represent the maximum kinetic energy of the electrons as a function of the frequency of the light for the new metal.

(b) With this new metal, the students find that no electrons are ejected from the metal if they shine red light on the metal. Two students make the following proposals.

Student <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> proposes that they try using a brighter red light to eject the electrons.

Student <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> proposes that they try using green light to eject the electrons.
Indicate which student’s proposal is more likely to produce ejected electrons. Justify your answer by referring to both proposals.
